section.title: Session Duration
section.para: A begins after a successful operation. The session ends after the Reading System has invoked the operation, or it may be terminated by the Service.

This specification does not define any behaviors regarding Service termination of Sessions; time out intervals, reasons for forced termination, and related aspects are all defined by the implementation.

A Session may cover multiple HTTP connections. Since transferring and rendering of content may be very time-consuming, Sessions should be kept open for as long as possible, in order to minimize the risk for a negative User experience.

section.title: Downloading and streaming of content

para.remark: Add whatever we need to say on this topic. Refer to Service Delegates. Note that download/streaming can occur after session termination.
Important things to include in this section:

section.para: If credentials are needed to access the Content, then the Service must supply the credentials in the URL of the resource. These credentials may be the same as the credentials, but the Reading System must not send basic authentication credentials if they were not supplied in the URL.
A DAISY Online session does not need to be active in order for a Reading System to download or stream Content.

Resources may be stored on the Service's servers or with Service Delegates, without restriction. Note that Service Delegates may require different credentials for access to resources, or may not require credentials at all. The Service must provide this information to Reading Systems.

Range headers for HTTP GET must be supported by the Service. Since there is no way to enforce this requirement on Service Delegates, Reading Systems must be able to handle servers that do not support range headers.

section.para: If Content is protected using , then there will be a metadata item in the named pdtb2:specVersion with a value of 2005-1 and there will be resources with mimeTypes beginning with application/x-pdtb…. The Reading System can access these resources even if it does not support , but it might not be able to decrypt all the Content.
If some Content has an Authorization Object (AO), the Reading System can inspect it for the name of the key that secures the key to decrypt the Content.

The Reading System may call with a list of names of keys on its keyring (these can be all or some of the symmetric keys or public/private keypairs the Reading System supports) and the name of the requested key. The Service is free to choose any of the keys in the supportedPublicKeyNames to encrypt the Key Exchange Object (KXO). If the Service does not have any of those keys or if the User is not authorized to access the Content, then the Service will instead reply with an . The Service is responsible for keeping a list of authorized key names.

example.title: An Encrypted DTB
example.para: A User wants to read an encrypted PDTB from the Zenith Library. The AO is itself encrypted with a key named DAISY.gy-zlog.afc26219-auth:

The User has keys for the Reading System (an Acme Reader Express) as well as user account keys supplied by Haute-Bibliothèque and Apex Talking Books, Inc. The Reading System calls the operation with the first parameter, supportedPublicKeyNames, as:
example.programlisting: <itemList> <!-- The vendor, model and instance keys of the reading system. --> <item>DAISY.lv-acme</item> <item>DAISY.lv-acme.ReaderExpress</item> <item>DAISY.lv-acme.0034218</item> <!-- User account keys granted by Haute-Bibliothèque and Apex. --> <item>DAISY.ca-qqhb.006442</item> <item>DAISY.au-atbi.userKey-4C452DB4</item> </itemList>
example.para: and the second parameter,requestedKeyName, as DAISY.gy-zlog.afc26219-auth.

The Service determines that the User is authorized to receive this key. The Service Provider has determined that the Acme Reader Express is a trusted Reading System model, so the Service returns a KXO encrypted with the model key, DAISY.lv-acme.ReaderExpress:
